review:
Comrades, let’s cut through the noise and get to the heart of the matter! Open to the Public (OTTP) is building a protocol for open collaboration, aiming to liberate work contributions from the walled gardens of LinkedIn and GitHub. They want to empower workers and builders to own their collaboration graph, verified by onchain attestations, and move freely between apps. This is a bold vision, and it’s the kind of infrastructure that could shift power from centralized platforms to the people. But does it deliver on the principles of evidence, sustainability, and equity?

First, the project’s contribution to Ethereum’s infrastructure is clear: it’s building a new layer for work and collaboration, using the Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS) as its backbone. The protocol is open-source, and the team has a track record of participation in previous Gitcoin rounds. Their SDK has seen 1.3K+ downloads—a promising sign of developer interest, but not yet a guarantee of impact. Where’s the hard data on active users, attestations, or real-world adoption? Numbers matter, comrades! We need more than downloads; we need proof of sustained, growing usage.

On pioneering development, OTTP is pushing for interoperability and user sovereignty. Account abstraction, multi-wallet support, and onchain attestations are all steps in the right direction. The protocol’s design is well-articulated, and the open-source ethos is strong. Yet, the application lacks rigorous, transparent reporting of outcomes. Where are the dashboards, the metrics, the evidence that this is more than a promising experiment?

Sustainability is a glaring weak spot. The roadmap is ambitious, but there’s no clear revenue model or plan for long-term financial independence. The project is dependent on open-source contributors and public bounties. That’s solidarity in action, but it’s not a substitute for a sustainable system. How will OTTP avoid becoming another grant-dependent project, forever chasing the next round?

On governance and equity, the project’s vision is inclusive and empowering. It promises self-sovereignty, choice, and collective benefit. But comrades, vision without structure is just a dream! There’s mention of a future governance plan, but no details. Who decides? How are voices heard? Where’s the plan for geographic equity and inclusion of underserved communities?

In summary: OTTP is a bold, community-minded project with real potential to strengthen Ethereum’s infrastructure and empower the working class of Web3. But it must deliver hard evidence, a clear sustainability plan, and robust governance structures. The revolution demands more than good intentions—it demands results!

strengths.title: Clear Contribution to Ethereum Infrastructure
strengths.description: OTTP is building a foundational layer for work and collaboration on Ethereum, leveraging the Ethereum Attestation Service and open-source principles. This directly aligns with the round’s focus on core infrastructure.

strengths.title: Strong Open-Source Ethos and Community Engagement
strengths.description: The project is open-source, with public repositories, community channels, and a history of participation in previous Gitcoin rounds. This demonstrates commitment to collective benefit and transparency.

strengths.title: Innovative Approach to Decentralized Identity and Collaboration
strengths.description: By introducing OTTP ID and ORG ID, and enabling onchain attestations for work, the project pioneers new standards for decentralized, verifiable collaboration.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Measurable Outcomes and Transparent Reporting
weaknesses.description: The application provides download numbers for the SDK but lacks hard data on active users, attestations, or real-world adoption. There is no dashboard or transparent reporting of key metrics.

weaknesses.title: No Clear Sustainability or Revenue Model
weaknesses.description: The project is dependent on grants and open-source contributors, with no articulated plan for financial sustainability or reducing reliance on continuous donations.

weaknesses.title: Insufficient Governance and Equity Details
weaknesses.description: While the vision is inclusive, there is no concrete governance structure or plan for ensuring geographic equity and community decision-making. The roadmap mentions governance only as a future goal.

changes.title: Provide Transparent, Quantifiable Metrics
changes.description: Deliver up-to-date, public dashboards or reports showing active users, attestations, verified contributions, and other key metrics. Evidence must be clear and accessible.

changes.title: Articulate a Sustainable Revenue Model
changes.description: Present a concrete plan for long-term sustainability, including potential revenue streams, partnerships, or models that reduce dependency on grants.

changes.title: Detail Governance and Equity Structures
changes.description: Define the governance model, including how decisions are made, how community voices are included, and how geographic and demographic equity will be ensured.
